content: How can I help you today?

Well, my wife asked me to talk to someone because things at home have been really tough. I just don't know if this is going to help. Our son is having a lot of issues, and honestly, it’s straining everything, including my marriage. I just feel stuck.

It sounds like you’re carrying a lot right now—worry about your son, the strain it’s putting on your marriage, and feeling uncertain about what to do next. That can feel heavy and overwhelming at times. What’s been the hardest part for you in all of this?

I think the hardest part is feeling like I’m failing as a parent and a husband. No matter what I do, I can’t fix things with my son, and because of that, my wife and I are constantly arguing. I feel like I'm letting everyone down.

That sounds incredibly painful, feeling torn between wanting to support your son, wanting to strengthen your relationship with your wife, and feeling like you’re not meeting those goals. There’s a deep sense of responsibility there, and it’s clear how much you care about both of them. What do you think makes you feel like you're failing despite how much effort you’re putting in?

I guess it’s because no matter how hard I try, nothing seems to get better. My son’s behavior hasn’t improved, my wife is upset a lot, and I just feel like I’m not enough for them. It’s like I’m fighting so hard, but still losing.

It sounds exhausting—giving so much of yourself and still feeling like your efforts aren’t making the impact you want. That sense of “fighting but still losing” can feel really defeating. At the same time, it shows how deeply you’re invested in your family and how much you care about their happiness. What keeps you going, even when it feels so difficult?

I guess what keeps me going is the hope that maybe, somehow, I can figure out a way to make things better. I want my son to be okay, I want my wife to feel supported, and I want to keep my family together. Even when it feels like everything is falling apart, I can’t let myself give up on them.

That hope you’re holding on to speaks volumes about your strength and commitment to your family. Even in the face of all these challenges, your drive to keep trying and not give up is really powerful. What do you think is the first small step that could help move things in a better direction for you and your family?

Maybe just trying to talk more openly with my wife about what we can do together? Or finding a better way to understand what’s going on with my son without everyone being so stressed. Honestly, I don’t even know if that’s the right step. Everything just feels so overwhelming right now.

Those sound like thoughtful and meaningful steps—wanting to communicate better with your wife and understand your son more deeply. It shows how much you want to work as a team and really get to the heart of what’s going on. It’s okay to feel unsure about where to start when things feel overwhelming. What would make it easier to take even a small step in one of those directions?

Maybe if my wife and I could have a conversation where we’re not just arguing, but actually working together, it would help. Or if there was someone to guide us on how to help our son, that might make it feel less impossible. Right now, everything just feels too big to handle alone.

It makes sense that everything feels overwhelming when it feels like you’re navigating so much on your own. Seeking a way to work together with your wife as a team and having guidance for supporting your son could help lift some of that weight and bring clarity. What would it look like for you to take a step toward having that kind of conversation with your wife or reaching out for support?

Maybe I could try to have a calm conversation with my wife about how we can approach this together without blaming each other. As for support, I don’t even know where to start. I’m hesitant about involving someone else, but at the same time, maybe it would help to not feel so alone in figuring this out.

Thinking about having a calm, open conversation with your wife shows you’re striving for connection and teamwork, even in the middle of a tough situation. It also sounds like you’re open to the idea of outside support, even if it feels a little uncertain right now. What would help give you more clarity or confidence about taking that step?

I think having some kind of plan or understanding what kind of help we’d be seeking might make it easier. If I knew that it wouldn’t just be someone judging us or telling us we’re doing everything wrong, I might feel more comfortable reaching out. It’s just hard to trust that it’ll actually make a difference.

It’s completely understandable to feel hesitant, especially when you want to make sure the support you seek will be helpful and not judgmental. It’s clear you’re looking for someone who will listen and guide, not criticize. What do you think you and your wife would want to gain from seeking that kind of help?

I think we’d want to understand our son’s behavior better and figure out how we can actually help him without feeling like we’re spinning our wheels all the time. And for my wife and me, I think we just need some tools to stop arguing and work together, instead of against each other. It’s hard to even know where to begin though.

It sounds like gaining understanding and having practical tools—both for supporting your son and fostering teamwork with your wife—are really important to you. Those are such meaningful goals and could make a big difference for everyone. Would it feel helpful to explore what taking that first step toward finding the right kind of support might look like? Or is there something else you’d like to focus on right now?

I guess exploring that first step could be a good idea, even if it feels a little uncomfortable. If it could actually help us take some of the pressure off and make things clearer, it might be worth it. I just wouldn’t really know where to start with finding the right kind of support.

It’s a big step to consider reaching out for support, and it’s completely normal to feel a bit uneasy about it. Taking this first step could be the start of easing that pressure you’ve been under. Would it help to look into resources like a family counselor or someone who specializes in working with parents and children? Or would you feel more comfortable starting with just a conversation with your wife to explore this together?
